column1: Nanuet is a hamlet and census-designated place in the town of Clarkstown
column4: United States. The third largest hamlet in Clarkstown

column8: and west of West Nyack. It is located midway between Manhattan and Bear Mountain

column1: The topography is a result of the massive glaciation of the last Ice Age
column2: and as such the soil is extremely rocky and the surface shows glacial erratic boulders. The glacial ice scraped off and carried with it rocks and minerals from as far north as Canada
column3: depositing them in Nanuet in particular and southern New York in general. This is the hypothesized source of the manganese-rich parvo-mangano-edenite minerals
column4: as well as the placer ore for gold panning within Nauraushaun Brook. There are fossil impressions of huge Precambrian Era jellyfish in the wooded
column5: undeveloped regions. One prominent surface feature
column6: a Hopewell Indian burial mound dating to 325 AD
column7: is located near Nauraushaun Brook at the western edge of the Manhattan Woods Golf Club in West Nyack. Aerial views of this feature reveal it to have been built in the shape of a snake.

column1: Lake Nanuet Park is a pool which is designed to look like a naturally occurring lake. The park which surrounds it offers residents a summer pool and recreational baseball/softball fields. Recent massive flooding and subsequent contamination closed the park for swimming until 2011.
